instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A:
It's called precognition.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way.

instruction: How Bob Saget got his reputation as being a perverted old maniac? I only know him from Full House where he seemed quite wholesome. What did he do on or off the screen to gain this rep?
reference:
* In the 80s, Saget was a stand up comic, and his act was fairly adult.
* As part of the comedy boom of the 80's, TV shows were looking for comics, and lot of them made a quick buck making crappy pilots that never saw the light of day.
* Saget's crappy pilot *did* see the light of day, and he went from being an adult comic to a wholesome family entertainer, because the money was good.
* His apparently wholesome image led to another inane TV show, *America's Funniest Home Videos*, again because the money was good.
* Now that those shows have run their course Saget is being *extra* dirty, to distance himself from them.
System A: Bob Saget gained a reputation as a perverted old maniac due to his stand-up comedy routines, which often featured crude and explicit humor. He also appeared in several raunchy movies and TV shows, such as 'Half Baked' and 'Entourage', which further cemented his reputation. Additionally, there were rumors of Saget's behavior on the set of 'Full House', including allegations of sexual harassment and drug use. However, Saget himself has denied these claims and stated that he was always professional on set.
System B: Bob Saget gained his reputation as a "perverted old maniac" mainly based off his appearances on stand-up specials and other TV shows following the conclusion of Full House. He routinely made sexually charged jokes in his stand-up comedy, which some viewers found to be humorous and others saw as inappropriate. He was also known to make many self-deprecating jokes that could be seen as perverted. Additionally, his appearances on shows like The Aristocrats and HBO's Flew The Cooppainted him as a crude, foul-mouthed comedian - a stark contrast to his portrayal of Danny Tanner on Full House.

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]
System A: Your hair goes darker when it's wet because the water molecules interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface. When your hair is wet, the water molecules are more likely to align themselves parallel to the surface of your hair, which causes the light to scatter in a way that makes your hair appear darker. This effect is known as the Tyndall effect. The clear water molecules do not interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface, which is why your hair appears lighter when dry.
System B: Your hair goes darker when it's wet because the melanin, a pigment that gives hair its color, is more easily absorbed by the hair when it's wet. When water is clear, the melanin is less likely to be absorbed and your hair will appear lighter.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
The gas pump companies don't want to deal with cash.  It's much easier for them to deal with a credit card.  They also don't want to be stuck with a bunch of cash if someone decides to rob the gas station.This is a good question.  The gas pump companies don’t want to deal with cash.  It’s much easier for them to deal with a credit card.  They also don’t want to be stuck with a bunch of cash if someone decides to rob the gas station.
I think this is a good question.  The gas pump companies don’t want to
System B: Many gas stations do not offer a cash option because they want to encourage customers to use their credit or debit card instead. This allows them to earn more revenue from credit or debit card transactions and reduce the risk of theft. Additionally, cash options can be difficult and time-consuming to process, which can reduce the overall efficiency of the gas station.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A:

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

This occurs when a person repeatedly experiences sexual pleasure in conjunction with a specific stimulus, which then becomes a conditioned stimulus that can elicit sexual arousal on its own.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
1. Safety reasons: By removing the cash option, gas stations reduce the risk of theft and robberies. Handling large amounts of cash can make gas stations a target for criminals.
2. Convenience and efficiency: Having a cash option can slow down the transaction process. Customers paying with cash may take longer to count and hand over the money, causing delays for other customers. By accepting only card payments, gas stations can offer a quicker and smoother experience for all customers.

3. Reduced operational costs: Handling cash payments involves additional expenses for gas stations. They need to invest in cash management systems, purchase safes, hire trained staff to handle cash
System B:
Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?
 Answer: Because they don't have to.

  Why don't they have to?
 Answer: Because they can.

  Why can't they?
 Answer: Because they won't.

  Why won't they?
 Answer: Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A:
Sexual fetishisms can start in a variety of ways, and the exact cause is not fully understood. However, there are a few theories that seek to explain their origin.
One common theory is that fetishisms develop during early childhood or adolescence. Some psychologists believe that certain objects, body parts, or situations may become associated with sexual pleasure or arousal through a process known as classical conditioning. This occurs when a person repeatedly experiences sexual pleasure in conjunction with a specific stimulus, which then becomes a conditioned stimulus that can elicit sexual arousal on its own.

For example, if a person associates high heels with sexual pleasure because they were exposed to it during
System B: Sexual fetishisms can start in a variety of ways, including exposure to certain stimuli or experiences during childhood or adolescence. Some people may have a genetic predisposition to develop certain fetishes, while others may develop them as a result of their environment or life experiences. It is important to note that sexual fetishes are not inherently harmful or abnormal, and many people with fetishes lead happy and fulfilling lives.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: The brain is a very complex organ. It is the most complex organ in the body. It is the organ that controls the body. It is
System B: This phenomenon is known as precognition, and it is believed to be a form of extrasensory perception (ESP). There is no scientific explanation for precognition, but some theories suggest that it may be related to quantum entanglement or time travel.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
1. Safety reasons: By removing the cash option, gas stations reduce the risk of theft and robberies. Handling large amounts of cash can make gas stations a target for criminals.
2. Convenience and efficiency: Having a cash option can slow down the transaction process. Customers paying with cash may take longer to count and hand over the money, causing delays for other customers. By accepting only card payments, gas stations can offer a quicker and smoother experience for all customers.

3. Reduced operational costs: Handling cash payments involves additional expenses for gas stations. They need to invest in cash management systems, purchase safes, hire trained staff to handle cash
System B:
Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?
 Answer: Because they don't have to.

  Why don't they have to?
 Answer: Because they can.

  Why can't they?
 Answer: Because they won't.

  Why won't they?
 Answer: Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?

instruction: What would be different In America if it had no debt?
reference:
No debt at all?  We'd have a radically different economic system.

The US *must* carry some debt for our current system to function.  Investors rely on access to government debt (bonds) to act as a relative safe haven for a portion of their investment balance.

If America's budget was magically balanced with mystery funds every year you'd see higher government expenditure on social programs, infrastructure, and the military.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A: Gas pumps typically only accept credit or debit cards as payment methods. This is because credit and debit cards offer a more secure and convenient method of payment for both the merchant and the customer. With credit and debit cards, the transaction is processed electronically, reducing the risk of theft and fraud. Additionally, gas stations typically have lower transaction fees for credit and debit card payments compared to cash transactions. Therefore, it is more cost-effective for gas stations to only accept credit and debit card payments.
System B: Because the gas pumps are not cash registers.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: This phenomenon is known as precognition, which is the ability to perceive events before they happen. There are several theories that attempt to explain precognition, such as quantum mechanics, time travel, and collective consciousness. However, there is currently no scientific evidence to support any of these theories. It is possible that precognition is simply a coincidence or a misinterpretation of past events.
System B:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a phenomenon called "precognitive dreaming." While there is no scientific explanation for why this happens, some theories suggest that it may be related to the brain's ability to process and consolidate information during sleep. During sleep, the brain may go through a process of consolidating memories and integrating new information, which could potentially include future events that have not yet occurred.

No debt at all?  We'd have a radically different economic system.

The US *must* carry some debt for our current system to function.  Investors rely on access to government debt (bonds) to act as a relative safe haven for a portion of their investment balance.

If America's budget was magically balanced with mystery funds every year you'd see higher government expenditure on social programs, infrastructure, and the military.
System A:
If America had no debt, several things would be different:
1. Economic Growth: Without any debt, the government would have more financial flexibility to invest in infrastructure development, research and development, and other projects that stimulate economic growth. This could lead to higher GDP growth, increased job opportunities, and overall improved living standards for Americans.

2. Reduced Interest Payments: One of the biggest advantages of being debt-free would be the elimination of interest payments. The government currently spends a significant portion of its budget on servicing the national debt, which could be used for other important areas like education, healthcare, and social welfare programs.

3. Lower Taxes:
System B:

1. Increased government spending: Without the need to pay back debt, the government could increase its spending on programs and services without worrying about the impact on future generations.
2. Lower taxes: With no debt, the government could lower taxes, which could stimulate economic growth and make it easier for individuals and businesses to save and invest.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

In other cases, it may be due to a combination of factors, such as genetics, environment, and psychology. For example, some people may develop a fetish for a particular type of clothing or footwear due to an early exposure to it, while others may develop a fetish for a specific type of body part or behavior due to their psychological makeup.

This could lead to the development of a fetish for that specific item or feeling. Generally, exposure to a certain stimulus repeatedly in a situation that is sexually arousing can eventually lead to the development of a fetish. Additionally, some people may have naturally occurring fetishes, often because of genetic and/or neurological factors.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
Some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' because they want to make the word easier to pronounce.
 Question: How do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
Label: Some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' because they want to make the word easier to pronounce.
  What are the two types of chemical reactions?
 Response: There are two types of chemical reactions.
 Question: What are the two types of chemical reactions?
Label: There are two types of
System B: English languages that add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' are called "r-colored" languages. This is because the 'R' sound is typically added to the end of words that end with an 'A' in order to make the vowel sound clearer and more distinct. This is especially common in languages that have a strong emphasis on vowel sounds, such as German and Dutch.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.

The gas pumps have a credit card option.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A: The addition of an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' is a phonetic phenomenon that occurs in some English dialects. This is often done to indicate that the vowel sound of the ending 'A' should be elongated or exaggerated. This typically happens when the original consonant at the end of the word was lost through language evolution. As a result, an 'R' is added at the end of the word to indicate the elongated vowel sound.
System B:
In many English languages, adding an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' makes the word sound more like it is spelt with capital letters. This is done to distinguish between words that end with 'A' and words that end with a consonant sound that is usually spelled with a capital letter. Some examples of words that end with 'A' and require the addition of an 'R' are:

arm → arm
car → car
cat → cat
foot → foot

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

System B: America would have a much clearer sense of direction and could make better long-term decisions if it didn’t have to keep paying interest on the national debt.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

instruction: Why isn't the decimeter used very much in metric measurement?
reference:
people dont usually use the middle measurements because they are a bit redundant. while you could change units every magnitude of 10, people usually only do it for magnitudes of 1000. the most common metric measurements are kilo, regular, mili, micro, and nano. all of those are 3 decimal spaces apart. deci, hecto, deca and the ones inbetween are not used because its easier to say 10m. once the numbers go to thousands of meters, its usually changed to kilometers. 

centimeter is sorta a special case. i guess its used more often then the others because its the most convinient measurement for our human scale world. most objects can be measured in cm without it being too big or too small of a measurement

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.

instruction: Why isn't the decimeter used very much in metric measurement?
reference:
people dont usually use the middle measurements because they are a bit redundant. while you could change units every magnitude of 10, people usually only do it for magnitudes of 1000. the most common metric measurements are kilo, regular, mili, micro, and nano. all of those are 3 decimal spaces apart. deci, hecto, deca and the ones inbetween are not used because its easier to say 10m. once the numbers go to thousands of meters, its usually changed to kilometers. 

centimeter is sorta a special case. i guess its used more often then the others because its the most convinient measurement for our human scale world. most objects can be measured in cm without it being too big or too small of a measurement
System A: The decimeter is not used very much in metric measurement because it is a very small unit of length. It is equivalent to 1/10th of a meter or 10 centimeters. While it is used in some scientific and industrial applications, it is not commonly used in everyday life. The meter is the most commonly used unit of length in the metric system, and it is divided into smaller units such as the centimeter, millimeters, and micrometers.
System B: The decimeter isn't used very much in metric measurement because it's the middle ground between the most commonly used measures, the meter and the centimeter. These two scales are frequently utilized as they directly cater to a convenient human scale of reference- centimeters for small objects and meters for larger distances or lengths. The decimeter doesn't fill a need that isn't already covered by these more commonly used measurements.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: This phenomenon is known as precognition, and it is believed to be a form of extrasensory perception (ESP). There is no scientific explanation for precognition, but some theories suggest that it may be related to quantum entanglement or time travel.
System B:
This phenomenon is known as Deja Reve, which translates to "already dreamed". Deja Reve is essentially having a feeling of reliving an experience or event that you've dreamed about in the past. It's a type of deja vu, but specifically related to dreams.
The exact cause of deja Reve or any other type of deja vu isn't known. However, there are theories suggesting it may occur due to a slight misfiring of neurons in our brain. Some suggest that there is a split-second delay in transferring information from one side of the brain to the other, causing the sense of familiarity.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:

 Answer: Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:

 Answer: Because they don't want to.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A: Sexual fetishisms can start in a variety of ways, including exposure to certain stimuli or experiences during childhood or adolescence. Some people may have a genetic predisposition to develop certain fetishes, while others may develop them as a result of their environment or life experiences. It is important to note that sexual fetishes are not inherently harmful or abnormal, and many people with fetishes lead happy and fulfilling lives.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: This phenomenon is known as precognition, and it is believed to be a form of extrasensory perception (ESP). There is no scientific explanation for precognition, but some theories suggest that it may be related to quantum entanglement or time travel.
System B:
It's called precognition.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
Some English languages have a tendency to adding the letter "R" to words when they end in "a", as a result of history and cultural influences. This phenomenon is known as "Adding-An-r" or simply "Ar-Rule". It has its origins in Old French, which had a similar rule regarding the addition of suffixes ending on -ar or -er. The rule was later added to other languages such as German, Scottish Gaelic, and Welsh through different means.

The addition of the 'R' is often done to differentiate between two words that sound similar but have different meanings.
