instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A: Sexual fetishisms can start in a variety of ways, including exposure to certain stimuli or experiences during childhood or adolescence. Some people may have a genetic predisposition to develop certain fetishes, while others may develop them as a result of their environment or life experiences. It is important to note that sexual fetishes are not inherently harmful or abnormal, and many people with fetishes lead happy and fulfilling lives.
System B: Sexual fetishisms can develop in many different ways. One common way for fetishism to begin is via association through repetitive exposure and imaginings. For example, a person might become aroused by an item or experience in the past, such as a certain texture or item of clothing. This could lead to the development of a fetish for that specific item or feeling. Generally, exposure to a certain stimulus repeatedly in a situation that is sexually arousing can eventually lead to the development of a fetish. Additionally, some people may have naturally occurring fetishes, often because of genetic and/or neurological factors.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: This phenomenon is known as precognition, and it is believed to be a form of extrasensory perception (ESP). There is no scientific explanation for precognition, but some theories suggest that it may be related to quantum entanglement or time travel.
System B:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a phenomenon called "precognitive dreaming." While there is no scientific explanation for why this happens, some theories suggest that it may be related to the brain's ability to process and consolidate information during sleep. During sleep, the brain may go through a process of consolidating memories and integrating new information, which could potentially include future events that have not yet occurred. 
It's also possible that precognitive dreaming is related to the brain's ability to generate and process hypothetical scenarios. During sleep, the brain may be more likely to

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A: Sexual fetishisms can start in a variety of ways, including exposure to certain stimuli or experiences during childhood or adolescence. Some people may have a genetic predisposition to develop certain fetishes, while others may develop them as a result of their environment or life experiences. It is important to note that sexual fetishes are not inherently harmful or abnormal, and many people with fetishes lead happy and fulfilling lives.
System B: Sexual fetishisms can develop in many different ways. One common way for fetishism to begin is via association through repetitive exposure and imaginings. For example, a person might become aroused by an item or experience in the past, such as a certain texture or item of clothing. This could lead to the development of a fetish for that specific item or feeling. Generally, exposure to a certain stimulus repeatedly in a situation that is sexually arousing can eventually lead to the development of a fetish. Additionally, some people may have naturally occurring fetishes, often because of genetic and/or neurological factors.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
Some English languages have a tendency to adding the letter "R" to words when they end in "a", as a result of history and cultural influences. This phenomenon is known as "Adding-An-r" or simply "Ar-Rule". It has its origins in Old French, which had a similar rule regarding the addition of suffixes ending on -ar or -er. The rule was later added to other languages such as German, Scottish Gaelic, and Welsh through different means.

The main idea behind this rule can be summarized as follows:

1.   Words
System B: English languages that add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' are called "r-colored" languages. This is because the 'R' sound is typically added to the end of words that end with an 'A' in order to make the vowel sound clearer and more distinct. This is especially common in languages that have a strong emphasis on vowel sounds, such as German and Dutch.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?
 Answer: Because they don't have to.

  Why don't they have to?
 Answer: Because they can.

  Why can't they?
 Answer: Because they won't.

  Why won't they?
 Answer: Because they don't want to.

  Why don't they want to?
System B: Because the gas pumps are not cash registers.

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]
System A: When hair is wet, the water swells and thickens the shaft of each strand of hair. As a result, more light is absorbed instead of reflected, which causes hair to appear darker.
System B:
This is a common phenomenon known as the "wet-bright effect." When hair is wet, the cuticle scales of the hair shaft are temporarily lifted, allowing more light to pass through the hair shaft. This causes the hair to appear lighter in color than when it is dry. When the hair dries, the cuticle scales close and the hair appears darker than when it was wet.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
1. Safety reasons: By removing the cash option, gas stations reduce the risk of theft and robberies. Handling large amounts of cash can make gas stations a target for criminals.
2. Convenience and efficiency: Having a cash option can slow down the transaction process. Customers paying with cash may take longer to count and hand over the money, causing delays for other customers. By accepting only card payments, gas stations can offer a quicker and smoother experience for all customers.

3. Reduced operational costs: Handling cash payments involves additional expenses for gas stations. They need to invest in cash management systems, purchase safes, hire trained staff to handle cash
System B: The gas pumps in my area don't have a cash option because the cash option is only available at the gas station's front desk.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
The addition of an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' in English is not a common feature of the language. However, there are a few exceptions where this rule applies. 
One example is the word 'baker', which ends with the letter 'A' but adds an 'R' to form the word 'baker'. This is because the 'A' in 'baker' is pronounced as a schwa sound (/ə/), which is a mid-central vowel sound that is not pronounced as clearly as other vowels. The addition of the 'R' helps to make the
System B:
Some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' in order to make them plural. For example, the word "apple" becomes "apples" when it is pluralized. This is known as the "R-controlled vowel" rule.

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]

This causes the hair to appear lighter in color than when it is dry. When the hair dries, the cuticle scales close and the hair appears darker than when it was wet.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A:
1. Safety reasons: By removing the cash option, gas stations reduce the risk of theft and robberies. Handling large amounts of cash can make gas stations a target for criminals.
2. Convenience and efficiency: Having a cash option can slow down the transaction process. Customers paying with cash may take longer to count and hand over the money, causing delays for other customers. By accepting only card payments, gas stations can offer a quicker and smoother experience for all customers.

3. Reduced operational costs: Handling cash payments involves additional expenses for gas stations. They need to invest in cash management systems, purchase safes, hire trained staff to handle cash
System B: The gas pumps in my area don't have a cash option because the cash option is only available at the gas station's front desk.

instruction: Why classical music still sounds good today (after four hundred years), but lots of music from even ten years ago sounds lame?
reference: When you hear classical music, you basically only hear the classical music that was good.  In the era of digitally recorded media, pretty much anyone with a microphone can record anything, and store it and transmit it anywhere for free, so it's easy to find the full range of music, from awesome to awful.
System A: Classical music is built on a foundation of a set of rules and conventions that have been established over the course of several hundred years. This means that it sounds good to us because it is consistent with our expectations. In contrast, contemporary music tends to be more experimental, and less consistent with our expectations. This means that it is harder for us to listen to it and enjoy it, because our brains have to work harder to make sense of it.It is important to note that this is not to say that contemporary music is always bad, or that classical music is always good. It is simply to say that our brains are hard-w
System B: Classical music is built on a foundation of well-crafted melodies, harmonies, and rhythms that have stood the test of time. It is also often performed by skilled musicians who have dedicated their lives to perfecting their craft. On the other hand, much of the music from ten years ago relied heavily on electronic sounds and production techniques that have become outdated and no longer hold up. Additionally, many of the songs from ten years ago were written and produced quickly to meet the demands of the music industry, rather than being crafted with care and attention to detail.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A: This phenomenon is known as precognition, which is the ability to perceive events before they happen. There are several theories that attempt to explain precognition, such as quantum mechanics, time travel, and collective consciousness. However, there is currently no scientific evidence to support any of these theories. It is possible that precognition is simply a coincidence or a misinterpretation of past events.
System B: This phenomenon of having seemingly prophetic dreams is known as precognitive dreaming. It is still not fully understood how or why these types of dreams occur. Some believe it could be a form of extra-sensory perception (ESP) where people are able to pick up on the energy of events before they happen. instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
Some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' because they want to make the word easier to pronounce.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A: Gas pumps typically only accept credit or debit cards as payment methods. This is because credit and debit cards offer a more secure and convenient method of payment for both the merchant and the customer. With credit and debit cards, the transaction is processed electronically, reducing the risk of theft and fraud. Additionally, gas stations typically have lower transaction fees for credit and debit card payments compared to cash transactions. Therefore, it is more cost-effective for gas stations to only accept credit and debit card payments.
System B: Not all gas pumps have a cash option due to a variety of reasons. The main reason is security concerns. Cash transactions can increase the risk of robberies and theft. Also, it's easier and more convenient for both customers and employees to handle transactions electronically. instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A:
Some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' because they want to make the word easier to pronounce.

Some examples of words that end with 'A' and require the addition of an 'R' are:

arm → arm
car → car
cat → cat
foot → foot

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

This could lead to higher GDP growth, increased job opportunities, and overall improved living standards for Americans.

2. Reduced Interest Payments: One of the biggest advantages of being debt-free would be the elimination of interest payments. The government currently spends a significant portion of its budget on servicing the national debt, which could be used for other important areas like education, healthcare, and social welfare programs.

people dont usually use the middle measurements because they are a bit redundant. while you could change units every magnitude of 10, people usually only do it for magnitudes of 1000. the most common metric measurements are kilo, regular, mili, micro, and nano. all of those are 3 decimal spaces apart. deci, hecto, deca and the ones inbetween are not used because its easier to say 10m. once the numbers go to thousands of meters, its usually changed to kilometers.

It is a subunit of the meter, which is the base unit of length in the metric system. The decimeter is equal to 10 decimeters, which is equal to 100 centimeters. This means that it is a very small unit of measurement, and it is typically only used in scientific or technical applications where very precise measurements are required.
System B: The decimeter is not used very much in metric measurement because it is not a commonly used unit of measurement. It is equivalent to one-tenth of a meter, which is a smaller unit of measurement than the centimeter, which is equivalent to one-hundredth of a meter. Therefore, the centimeter is more commonly used in metric measurement.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A: Gas pumps typically only accept credit or debit cards as payment methods. This is because credit and debit cards offer a more secure and convenient method of payment for both the merchant and the customer. With credit and debit cards, the transaction is processed electronically, reducing the risk of theft and fraud. Additionally, gas stations typically have lower transaction fees for credit and debit card payments compared to cash transactions. Therefore, it is more cost-effective for gas stations to only accept credit and debit card payments.
System B: Not all gas pumps have a cash option due to a variety of reasons. The main reason is security concerns. Cash transactions can increase the risk of robberies and theft. Also, it's easier and more convenient for both customers and employees to handle transactions electronically. Lastly, cash transactions also require the station to have more employees to handle cash, count it, and deposit it in the bank, which can increase labor costs.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A: Sexual fetishisms are developed in early childhood. The brain is developing very quickly during childhood and is very sensitive to environmental influences. Children learn to associate certain objects, situations, or people with sexual pleasure. This can lead to sexual fetishes that persist into adulthood.

As a way to increase the excitement and intensity of sexual experiences. Sexual fetishism can be triggered by any number of factors, including previous intense sexual experiences, past traumas or negative emotions related to sex, specific physical characteristics, certain objects or materials that have a strong association with sex (for example, leather or chastity belts), even certain body parts such as genitals or nipples when they are exposed for prolonged periods of time.\n\# What is the importance of keeping things simple in your instructions to yourself when it comes to these topics?

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.
System A:
It's possible that you're experiencing lucid dreaming. Lucid dreaming is the phenomenon of being aware that you're dreaming while you're in a dream, and having the ability to control some aspects of the dream.
In a lucid dream, you may be able to recall past experiences, create new experiences, and manipulate the environment in ways that you wouldn't be able to in real life. This can happen because your mind is more aware and active in a lucid dream than it is in real life, and you may be able to use this awareness to affect the events of the dream.

It's also possible that
System B:
This phenomenon is known as Deja Reve, which translates to "already dreamed". Deja Reve is essentially having a feeling of reliving an experience or event that you've dreamed about in the past. It's a type of deja vu, but specifically related to dreams.
The exact cause of deja Reve or any other type of deja vu isn't known. However, there are theories suggesting it may occur due to a slight misfiring of neurons in our brain. Some suggest that there is a split-second delay in transferring information from one side of the brain to the other, causing the sense of familiarity.

One plausible idea is that Deja

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.
System A: This is a feature of English called 'rhoticity', which refers to the pronunciation of the 'R' sound at the end of a syllable. Some English languages, such as American English and Irish English, are rhotic, meaning they pronounce the 'R' sound in words like 'car' and'star'. Other English languages, such as Scottish English and Australian English, are non-rhotic, meaning they do not pronounce the 'R' sound in these words. The addition of an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' is a common feature of rhotic
System B:
The addition of an 'R' to words that end with an 'A' in some English languages is known as rhoticism. Rhotic accents or dialects pronounce the 'R' sound at the end of words, even if it is not indicated in the spelling. This phenomenon is mainly found in certain English varieties, such as American English, some Scottish accents, and some dialects in Ireland, Canada, and the United States.
The historical reason for the addition of an 'R' can be traced back to the development of the English language. During the Middle English period, which roughly spanned the 11th to the

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.
System A: Sexual fetishisms are developed in early childhood. The brain is developing very quickly during childhood and is very sensitive to environmental influences. Children learn to associate certain objects, situations, or people with sexual pleasure. This can lead to sexual fetishes that persist into adulthood.
System B:
As a way to increase the excitement and intensity of sexual experiences. instruction: Why isn't the decimeter used very much in metric measurement?
reference:
people dont usually use the middle measurements because they are a bit redundant. while you could change units every magnitude of 10, people usually only do it for magnitudes of 1000. the most common metric measurements are kilo, regular, mili, micro, and nano. all of those are 3 decimal spaces apart. deci, hecto, deca and the ones inbetween are not used because its easier to say 10m. once the numbers go to thousands of meters, its usually changed to kilometers. 

centimeter is sorta a special case. i guess its used more often then the others because its the most convinient measurement for our human scale world. most objects can be measured in cm without it being too big or too small of a measurement
System A: The decimeter is not used very much in metric measurement because it is not commonly needed for everyday measurements. The metric system is based on powers of 10, which means that most measurements can be easily converted between different units by moving the decimal point. The decimeter is simply not as convenient or practical for most measurements as other metric units like the meter or centimeter. Additionally, there are other metric units that are more commonly used for specific purposes, such as the liter for measuring volume or the gram for measuring mass. Overall, the decimeter is not widely used in metric measurement due to its limited practicality and the availability of more commonly
System B: The decimeter isn't used very much in metric measurement because it's the middle ground between the most commonly used measures, the meter and the centimeter. These two scales are frequently utilized as they directly cater to a convenient human scale of reference- centimeters for small objects and meters for larger distances or lengths. The decimeter doesn't fill a need that isn't already covered by these more commonly used measurements.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A: Gas pumps may not have a cash option for a few reasons. Some pumps may require customers to use a debit or credit card for fraud prevention purposes. Additionally, many pumps are regulated by the government and require customers to pay with a form of electronic payment. Finally, cashless transactions are generally considered to be more secure and require less maintenance for gas stations.
System B: When you approach the counter to buy a car air freshener or coffee, a member of our staff will assist you in finding your desired product. They will also ask for any additional items that may be required (e.g., plastic bags if needed). Once they find an available system inside our store room, an employee will bring out the products and load them onto the shelves on the self-checkout station. The customer can then proceed to check their loyalty balance through a touch screen display on the same terminal as they scan each item. If they need help with anything else such as redeeming points or

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]
System A: When hair is wet, it appears darker because the water saturates the hair shaft and allows the hair to absorb light rather than reflect it, which gives it a darker appearance. This has nothing to do with the color of the water itself. The transparency of water only allows us to see the change more prominently.
System B: When your hair is wet, the water molecules are able to penetrate deeper into the hair shaft. This causes the hair to absorb more melanin, which is the pigment that gives hair its color. As a result, your hair appears darker when it's wet than when it's dry. Additionally, water is clear, so when it's absorbed into the hair shaft, it doesn't affect the color of the hair at all.

instruction: why is Puerto Rico broke?
reference: The big, ELI5 picture? They are compelled to abide by certain U.S. policy (like medicare/medicaid), but because they aren't a state don't get federal fund to cover. For a time, congress set up tax benefits for businesses to locate in PR and that helped boost jobs, taxes and pay for these programs. Then Congress repealed the laws, the companies left, so more people needed government assistance and at the same time the tax revenues to cover these programs were drastically cut.
System A: Puerto Rico's financial crisis is due to several factors. The territory has been suffering from long-term economic stagnation and the declining population, leading to less tax revenue and more infrastructure costs. Other factors include substantial government debts and public pension obligations which Puerto Rico cannot pay due to their economic conditions. Also, the government has provided generous tax incentives to big corporations in an effort to stimulate the economy, but this strategy failed to foster long-term, sustainable economic growth. Lastly, the frequent natural disasters, like Hurricane Maria, have severely impacted their economy and infrastructure, adding to the expenses the country cannot afford.
System B:
Puerto Rico is broke because they don't pay taxes.
 Question: Why is Puerto Rico broke?

Output: Puerto Rico is broke because they don't pay taxes.

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]
System A: When water is clear and comes in contact with your hair, hydrogen bonds are formed between the water molecules and the hydrogen atoms in your hair. The hydrogen atoms in the hydrogen bonds are attracted to the hydrogen atoms in your hair, and pull your hair into the water. This process removes the hydrogen atoms from the hydrogen bonds and darkens your hair.
System B: Your hair goes darker when it's wet because the water molecules interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface. When your hair is wet, the water molecules are more likely to align themselves parallel to the surface of your hair, which causes the light to scatter in a way that makes your hair appear darker. This effect is known as the Tyndall effect. The clear water molecules do not interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface, which is why your hair appears lighter when dry.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

The addition of the 'R' is often done to differentiate between two words that sound similar but have different meanings. instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]
System A: When water is clear and comes in contact with your hair, hydrogen bonds are formed between the water molecules and the hydrogen atoms in your hair. The hydrogen atoms in the hydrogen bonds are attracted to the hydrogen atoms in your hair, and pull your hair into the water. This process removes the hydrogen atoms from the hydrogen bonds and darkens your hair.
System B: Your hair goes darker when it's wet because the water molecules interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface. When your hair is wet, the water molecules are more likely to align themselves parallel to the surface of your hair, which causes the light to scatter in a way that makes your hair appear darker. This effect is known as the Tyndall effect. The clear water molecules do not interfere with the reflection of light on your hair's surface, which is why your hair appears lighter when dry.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.
System A: Many modern gas pumps have a credit or debit card option instead of a cash option. This is because most gas stations do not want to keep large amounts of cash on hand. If a customer wants to pay with cash, the cash must be brought to the pump by the customer, which requires management of cash on the part of the gas station, as well as the risk that the cash will be stolen or lost.
System B:
The gas pump companies don't want to deal with cash.  It's much easier for them to deal with a credit card.  They also don't want to be stuck with a bunch of cash if someone decides to rob the gas station.This is a good question.  The gas pump companies don’t want to deal with cash.
